page.title: 06GAMEKEEPING IN THE DALE.
page.content: Much of this area is open moorland used for grouse shooting. A{gamekeeper and{underkeeper}care for{10,000 } {acres}of moor which is owned by a Swede. The gamekeeper gets up early to shoot foxes and to set{fen traps}to kill stoats. The fox and stoats would kill the grouse chicks and the stoats eat the eggs. In March, before the grouse start laying, the heather is burnt. This encourages fresh growth and insects for the chicks to feed on. Every year 500 acres of heather are burnt. To do this the gamekeeper takes heather burners and heather beaters onto the moor. The burners are a stick with a cloth tied onto the end. This is soaked in paraffin. The beater puts out the fire. Other jobs that the gamekeeper does are the training of his dogs, building shooting butts and maintaining the moor roads.
